page.text: Select the numeric variable to test. After, select the factor and their two levels to compare.

Select the type of alternative hypothesis and specify which mean you theorize to be greater. Select two-sided, if your theory does not tell you, which variable is greater. If your hypothesis is directed, selecting a directional test hypothesis may increase test power.

Check the box if you have some evidence of the equality of variances (eg. via a F-test). An appropriate correction will be applied then that may increase test power. However, it's generally safe not to assume the variables have equal variances, if you don't have evidence.

Sometimes it's helpful to get an estimate of the confidence interval of the difference in means. Below you can specify whether one should be shown, and which confidence-level should be applied (95% corresponds to a 5% level of significance).
